metadata.name: Ecos de Calma #74
metadata.description:
Through algorithms and javascript code, each artwork comes to life with unique patterns and forms, evoking a sense of inner peace. The careful selection of the color palette recreates the magic of the transition between the softness of morning or evening light, with warm and subtle tones that intertwine in harmony.

'Ecos de Calma' invites viewers to explore their own sense of serenity and find moments of calmness in contemplating these generative creations. Let yourself be enveloped by the experience and immerse yourself in the subtle nuances and harmony of each color palette, where the moon and the tree come together to create a scene of tranquility and beauty.

Features:
15 Color Palettes.
5 Canvas Sizes.
Moon: Full Moon / Waning Crescent.
One or two hills.

Press "S" to download the image.

Created by Fernando Cabral.

metadata.name: RGB Elementary Cellular Automaton #181
metadata.description:
Stephen Wolfram's Elementary Cellular Automaton where 3 different rules are drawn in the Red, Green and Blue color components of the image.

Rules are selected randomly among a pre-selection of 53 rules from which nice behaviors emerge.

Tokens can have a cell size in the [1; 20] range.

metadata.name: Crash Euphoria #190
metadata.description:
My first foray into shaders and GLSL: This piece experiments with layering many textures guided by an underlying pattern. Each pixel value dictates which pattern is displayed. There are varying levels of imperfections in each pattern, some choose a single color, some use a color guide pattern, some individual strokes decide on another color altogether. These layers are compiled in a shader and warped.

Press 's' in live view to save a png

Created with p5.js and chroma.js

metadata.name: Shattered Obelisks #256
metadata.description:
Shattered Obelisks began as a work that is dedicated to my habit of mindlessly drawing on paper when I am stressed, depressed or immersed in difficult thoughts.

Like a patient undergoing psychotherapy and piecing together the causes of unconscious fears and anxieties, I and my artwork have assembled ourselves into something shaped, found order in the chaos and separated it from the external noise.

It took 3 months of continuous, obsessive work. I have developed a huge library, designed for hand-like drawing. The functionality of this library is four times larger than what is shown in this drop.

I plan to put this library out into the public domain when I deem it complete, and hope that it will help someone express themselves through the creative process as much as it helped for me.

In case you've encountered a problem with inverted colours, try changing browser or disabling extensions. This problem only occurred once during testing on a massive amount of devices and was resolved by disabling extensions.

IMPORTANT NOTES BLOCK:

NOTE 1: This artwork should be viewed at a browser scale of 100%. Reducing the scale will increase the amount of detail, but may unpredictably affect the preservation of the location of secondary objects.

NOTE 2: This work can be printed on a plotter. Click S for saving it in .SVG.
Detailed instructions and answers to possible questions can be found in the console output of the code.

NOTE 3: This drop is the first one from the series of 3. It will be used as AL ticket in next drops of this series.

@abakshonokoleg
01.08.2022
Tech: P5.JS
License: CC BY-SA 4.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0/)

attributes.name: Obelisk color
attributes.value: Depressed by the Void (Black & Purple & Blue)

metadata.name: Euphonic #725
metadata.description:
Euphonic is an exploration of the emergent visual properties that arise from placing layers of simple lines atop one another.

In general this effect is called the Moiré effect. This effect really feels best in the tactile - when you have a printed page and an acetate sheet. This piece attempts to recreate that tactile joy.

This is built in WebGL 2 and so doesn't work in Safari 14 and below. All latest browsers will work as expected.

Licensing: BY-NC-ND see license.md for details.

metadata.name: g a t e #496
metadata.description: The capture misses some detail, for full res open in live mode and press "s" to download full detail and high quality

metadata.name: Apertum #13
metadata.description:
Welcome to 'Apertum', a project that combines simple geometric elements with the unpredictability of randomness. It starts with triangles and lines and results in a diverse array of formations.

In 'Apertum', you will find a series of transformations and reshuffles, as well as a vibrant mix of textures and patterns. These interactions give rise to intricate compositions that I hope you'll enjoy discovering.

'Apertum' is both a thank you to those who have supported my work so far and an invitation to those new to my creations. I invite you to step into the world of 'Apertum', to discover its interplay of shapes, colors, and textures.

Press [s] to save a .png file of the artwork. Made with p5.js

Rob Scalera | 2023

metadata.name: Abstract #58 #42
metadata.description:
Abstract image created using p5js, Mark Walhimer, 2023
With added scrape layer

metadata.name: Uninhabitable #172
metadata.description:
Uninhabitable is a generative system built only from ellipses. The process of playing with different geometric and trigonometric disruptions gives rise to four different compositions which seek to evoque living constructions and environments. Besides the shape itself and its related distortion, the stroke weight of the lines plays a meaningful role in the piece. Following a discrete range [0.01,0.1,1] the weight reveals the process allowing the viewer to realize the trace of the huge amount of lines in each piece. This back and forth between scales and context is, while kind of stripping the code, part of my continuing interest on understanding the -usually- crazy paths of machines' way of thinking.

Press "h" to see it and high resolution and refresh to get back to the initial state. Press "h" to save it.

Uninhabitable is an original work by Iskra Velitchkova. 2021.

metadata.name: Abstract #58 #41
metadata.description:
Abstract image created using p5js, Mark Walhimer, 2023

metadata.name: Artifice #365
metadata.description:
This series is is about playful obfuscation.

The fxtext article linked on the main profect goes more in-depth into what is meant by that, as well as the events that led to this collection.

5640 bytes of Vanilla JS with no libraries. Palettes make up a third of the code.

In live mode:
‘S’ : save as png (3000 × 3600)
’V’ : save as svg (without grain)

URL params in live mode:
‘g=n’ : no grain
‘g=p’ : paper grain
‘h=t’ : high resolution mode, 9000 ×10600 (Chrome only, and may take a moment)

For example, if you wanted paper grain in high resolution, append “&g=p&h=t” to the url in live mode.

After rendering with these params, tapping 'P' will then save a png with those settings applied.

metadata.name: Commune #74
metadata.description:
A minimalist composition with a nod towards architecture.

2932 bytes of Vanilla JS.

For more info, see article linked below: Me, Commune, Etc.

In live mode:
’S’ : save as svg (without grain)
‘P’ : save as png (3780x2673)

URL params in live mode:
‘g=n’ : no grain
‘g=w’ : wood grain
‘h=t’ : high resolution mode, 7560 × 5346 (Chrome only)

After rendering with these params, tapping 'P' will then save the png with those settings applied.

metadata.name: Verdant Brut #158
metadata.description:
Verdant translates to “lush, green” and Brut means “dry, raw, or unrefined.”

This series is less about impressions of nature, or vegetal growth… but rather the vibrant, lush world that abstract art can provide and while certain iterations may serve Brutalist aesthetics, it tries to focus on the unrefined/raw aspect of the definition with more fluid shapes that feel irregular and organic in a playful, almost adolescent way.

Palettes inspired by MOMO, Melissa Wiederrecht, Erik Swahn, Marcelo Soria-Rodríguez, Paul Klee, Mareva Millarc, Ernst Mether-Borgström, Douglas Herbert Courtenay Auburn, Jim Harris, Alayne Spafford, Man Ray, Lajos Kassak and William Lachance. While the palettes may not always reflect their trademark colors (if they even have any) they are an homage to individual pieces by the respective artists that have influenced this series in their own way.

4878 bytes of Vanilla JS with no libraries.

For more info on the chosen palettes and other inspirations, see article linked from the main project page: Regarding Verdant Brut

In live mode:
‘S’ : save as png (2376 × 3360)
’V’ : save as svg (without grain)

URL params in live mode:
‘g=n’ : no grain
‘g=p’ : paper grain
‘h=t’ : high resolution mode, 5940 × 8400 (Chrome only)

For example, if you wanted paper grain in high resolution, append “&g=p&h=t” to the url in live mode.

After rendering with these params, tapping 'P' will then save the png with those settings applied.

metadata.name: Self, Id #197
metadata.description:
The first installment of the Self trilogy.

Id is defined as: the one of the three divisions of the psyche in psychoanalytic theory that is completely unconscious and is the source of psychic energy derived from instinctual needs and drives.

Please see attached fx(text) article or go to https://ty-vek.art/self-trilogy for more on concept/mechanics/etc. It’s a bit of long read, but worth it.

—————————

All projects are written in vanilla Javascript, composed as SVG and then rendered to a 2d canvas.

There might be slight differences in rendering from browser to browser. This is expected as they might translate the SVG slightly differently. Let's call Chromium renderings canonical. They also render faster there and we love that.

Press "S" to save a PNG.
Press "V" to save a SVG. (Chromium browsers render these pretty well.)

By default, these will render at 2400 x 3200 pixels. This is at density 1.

To render at a larger resolution you can append “&d=2” to the end of the url. This will double the resolution. You can also use 3 or 4 or whatever your browser can handle. Safari tends to have problems with this, so stick with Chromium based browsers (Chrome, Edge, Brave, etc.)

If you want to render as a square image, so it is optimized for ummm.. your pfp or something, you can append “&sq=t” to the url.

If you want to get rid of grain, just append “&g=n”

—————————

https://ty-vek.art/self-trilogy
https://twitter.com/ty__vek
https://www.fxhash.xyz/u/Ty%20Vek/articles

metadata.name: Cozy Mess #30
metadata.description:
This work is based and built on a single palette that I assembled from "natural tones" make-up catalogs and colors.
Anything that promotes artificial means of seeking what's natural, is fascinating to me, so I tried different methods of mixing and blending these colors in a make-upish kind of way.
Although I only applied them to very flat -expanse like- surfaces, I think Mr. Dither did a pretty good job of binding both the technical and conceptual sides of the work.

metadata.name: White Season #17
metadata.description:
White Season
This is part of the change over time.
I use white to schedule tasks at the right time for certain things.
It's a beautiful change, like winter, summer, or rainy season.
Never ending creation
And it's the right time on Fxhash.
Have fun and enjoy the changing white seasons.

Thank you for your support.

Image size: 3000 x 3000 pixels.
